title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak announces UK budget 2021
content:
Chancellor Rishi Sunak delivered his Spring Budget statement in the House of Commons on Wednesday.  The announcement comes against a backdrop of significant economic damage from the COVID-19 pandemic, which has seen over 700,000 job losses and a 10% contraction in the economy.

A key element of the budget was the extension of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS), which pays 80% of furloughed employees' wages.  The scheme will now continue until September, with employers contributing 10% of the cost in July, rising to 20% in August and September.  Support for self-employed individuals will also continue, with a further grant covering February to April.

Further worker support includes an increase in the National Living Wage to £8.91 per hour from April, and an extension of the £20 weekly increase to Universal Credit until September.

Taxation changes include a rise in corporation tax to 25% from April 2023.  Sunak described this as the lowest rate in the G7,  emphasizing that only companies with profits exceeding £250,000 (approximately 10% of companies) will be affected by the increase.  Companies with profits below £50,000 will continue to pay 19% corporation tax.  Income tax, National Insurance, and Capital Gains Tax will remain unchanged, along with a freeze on alcohol and fuel duty.

The reduced 5% VAT rate for the hospitality sector will continue.  The National Insurance threshold will increase from £45,000 to £100,000 this year.  Finally, new freeports were announced for:  [List Locations –  insert missing locations here].  These freeports aim to reduce customs costs and stimulate investment.
question:
What was announced by Rishi Sunak regarding corporation tax in the UK?

A) It will remain at 19%  
B) It will increase to 25% in April 2023  
C) It will decrease to 15%  
D) It will be eliminated for all companies

title: International Criminal Court to investigate war crimes in Palestine
content:
The International Criminal Court (ICC) announced on Wednesday that it will formally investigate alleged war crimes in Palestine, a decision that has drawn immediate condemnation from Israel and the United States.  The investigation, which will focus on events since June 13, 2014, will be led by a British lawyer who is to replace outgoing Chief Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda on June 16th.

Bensouda, whose office conducted a nearly five-year preliminary examination concluding that war crimes had been or were being committed in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip,  stressed the investigation would be "principled, non-partisan, independent, impartial, and objective."  She named both the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) and the Palestinian militant group Hamas as potential perpetrators, adding that investigation priorities will be determined later.

Palestine, an ICC member since 2015, has long accused Israel of war crimes.  Israel, however, is not an ICC member and rejects the court's jurisdiction, arguing Palestine lacks sovereignty.  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denounced the decision as "the essence of anti-Semitism and hypocrisy," claiming the ICC ignores other alleged war crimes committed by Iran and Syria, among others.  He further asserted that the IDF takes precautions to avoid civilian casualties, while Hamas deliberately targets civilians, and vowed to fight the decision.  Foreign Minister [Foreign Minister's name needed] echoed this sentiment, calling the decision "morally bankrupt and legally flawed."

The United States, also not an ICC member, has previously imposed sanctions on the prosecutor's office under the Trump administration.  [Name of person or group] urged President Biden to maintain these sanctions, describing the ICC investigation as "illegitimate and politically motivated."  The US also opposes an ICC investigation into US forces in Afghanistan.

A spokesperson for the US State Department stated that the US "will continue to uphold our strong commitment to Israel and its security" and that the ICC "has no jurisdiction over this matter."  The Israeli ambassador to the US pledged continued cooperation with the US.

The Palestinian National Authority welcomed the ICC's decision as a "long-awaited step" towards justice and accountability, urging nations not to politicize the proceedings.  Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem, who previously defended the group's 2014 rocket attacks on Israel as legal, hailed the decision as a step towards justice for the Palestinian people.

The 2014 Gaza conflict, known as Operation Protective Edge in Israel, resulted in significant casualties.  UN estimates place Palestinian deaths at 2200, including 1500 civilians, while Israeli estimates report at least 73 deaths, including six civilians.  The Associated Press reported that Israel has engaged in extensive public relations and diplomatic efforts to prevent this investigation.
question:
What is the focus of the International Criminal Court's investigation announced by Chief Prosecutor Bensouda?  

A) Alleged war crimes committed by Palestinian militant groups  
B) Alleged war crimes committed by the Israeli Defense Forces  
C) Alleged war crimes committed since June 13, 2014, in Palestine  
D) Alleged violations of international law by the United States

title: Wales widens smoking ban, includes at hospitals, schools and playgrounds
content:
## Wales Expands Smoking Ban to Hospitals, Schools, and Playgrounds

Wales has become the first UK nation to extend its smoking ban to encompass hospital grounds, school grounds, and playgrounds.  Violators will face a £100 fine.  This latest measure builds upon existing legislation, including a 2007 ban on smoking in enclosed public spaces and a 2015 ban on smoking in cars carrying children.

The Welsh government, led by the [Party Name], stated the aim is to discourage smoking by reducing its visibility, particularly among children, and to encourage smokers to quit.  Two hospitals in south Wales have even installed button-activated speakers to remind visitors of the smoke-free policy – a strategy previously piloted across the country in 2016 using announcements recorded by schoolchildren.

Minister for Mental Health, Wellbeing, and the Welsh Language, Eluned Morgan, expressed pride in the new law, highlighting its potential to improve the health of future generations by minimizing children's exposure to smoking.  She emphasized the government's commitment to combating the harmful effects of smoking.

However, the ban has drawn criticism from smokers' rights groups.  Simon Clark, Director of [Group Name], described the law as "a sledgehammer to crack a nut," arguing there's no evidence that open-air smoking poses a risk to others, including children. He also criticized the targeting of stressed smokers seeking comfort in a cigarette and asserted that most smokers already exercise common sense regarding children.

Wikinews contacted Minister Morgan's office for further comment.  The government clarified its objectives: to protect people from second-hand smoke, aid smokers trying to quit, and decrease the likelihood of children starting to smoke.  They reiterated their commitment to expanding smoke-free zones to outdoor areas of cafes, restaurants, and city centers.

Responding to accusations of micromanaging people's lives, the government emphasized the law's focus on public health, both by preventing second-hand smoke exposure and supporting smokers' cessation efforts. They hope to denormalize smoking among young people, reducing initiation rates.

Regarding individual rights, the government acknowledged smoking's status as a leading cause of preventable death in Wales and stated the legislation aims to combat its harmful effects while still allowing adults to smoke in designated areas.  The current ban applies to all areas specified in the legislation.  Playgrounds are completely smoke-free at all times, regardless of children's presence.  The government believes this comprehensive approach is essential to reduce smoking initiation amongst young people.


**Core Objective of the Law:** To protect public health by reducing exposure to second-hand smoke, assisting smokers in quitting, and preventing children from taking up smoking.

**Future of Smoking in Wales (if the law is successful):** A significant reduction in smoking rates, particularly among young people, and a greater number of smoke-free public spaces.  The ultimate aim is a healthier population with fewer smoking-related illnesses.

A) £50  
B) £100  
C) £200  
D) £150

title: Fundraiser Captain Sir Tom Moore dies aged 100 with COVID-19
content:
Captain Sir Tom Moore, 100, died Tuesday in a hospital in Bedford, England, after a battle with COVID-19 and pneumonia.  Last year, he raised nearly £33 million for the National Health Service (NHS) by walking 100 laps around his garden before his 100th birthday.  A World War II veteran who served in the British Army, he was a true national hero.

His daughters announced his passing, stating, "The last year of our father's life was nothing short of remarkable. He was an incredible father and grandfather, and he will stay in our hearts forever."

Born in Keighley, West Yorkshire, Moore joined the British Army in 1939.  Following his service, he worked as an instructor at the Armoured Fighting Vehicle School in Bovington, Dorset. He moved to Bedfordshire in 2007 to be closer to his family.

In April 2020, his initial goal to raise £1,000 for the NHS during the COVID-19 pandemic blossomed into a nationwide fundraising phenomenon.  He smashed the record for the most raised by an individual doing a charity walk and even reached number one on the UK charts with a duet with singer Michael Ball.  On his 100th birthday, April 30th, he was appointed an honorary colonel by the British Army, and in July, he was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed Moore as "a hero in the truest sense of the word," stating he "embodied the triumph of the human spirit."  Labour leader Keir Starmer echoed the sentiment, calling him "a British hero."  Buckingham Palace announced the Queen would send a private message of condolence.  Flags at government buildings, including 10 Downing Street, were flown at half-mast as a mark of respect.

Despite previous health challenges, including a head injury and a broken hip in 2018, Moore's hospital treatment inspired his fundraising efforts. He often praised the "marvellous" NHS staff who cared for him. He is survived by two daughters and four grandchildren.
question:
Who was honored by the British Army as an honorary colonel on his 100th birthday? 

A) Boris Johnson  
B) Elizabeth II  
C) Captain Tom Moore  
D) A spokesman for the Labour Party

title: Wikinews 2020: An 'Original reporting' year in review
content:
## Wikinews 2020: A Year in Review – From Indian Railways to Exoplanets

Wikinews' English-language section had a busy 2020, publishing over two dozen original reports.  Here's a look back at some highlights:

**Celebrating Women in Indian Railways:**  In a ten-day International Women's Day celebration themed "Each for Equal," an all-female crew, led by locomotive pilots B Shiva Parvathi and Rangoli Patil, operated the Mysuru-Bengaluru train in Karnataka, India.  This event highlighted the underrepresentation of women in the Indian Railways, with Mysore Divisional Railway Manager Aparna Garg noting that only about 10% (approximately 650 out of 6900) of employees are women.  Garg discussed the societal challenges women face in achieving professional success and the need for a broader societal shift in mindset to foster greater equality.


**Toilet Paper Shortages Amidst the Pandemic:** The spread of SARS-CoV-2 led to widespread panic buying, notably of toilet paper.  Australian retailers Woolworths and Coles initially limited purchases to four packs, but quickly reduced this to one or two due to high demand.  Even recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap experienced stockouts, despite working around the clock to meet demand.

**Iranian Chess Player Dorsa Derakhshani:** Wikinews interviewed International Master Dorsa Derakhshani, who was banned from representing Iran in 2017 for not wearing a hijab.  Derakhshani discussed the challenges faced by women chess players in Iran, the limited opportunities for competition, and the lack of support from fellow Iranian players after her ban.  She now studies in the United States and plays for the US team, citing the Polgár sisters, particularly Judit Polgár, as inspirations.

**Empathy in Rats and Brain Function:** A March study examined harm aversion in rats, revealing the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) as a crucial brain region for this behavior. Researchers observed that rats avoided harming conspecifics even when offered rewards, and this aversion was lost after ACC deactivation.

**Discovery of the Closest Known Black Hole:** Researchers from the European Southern Observatory announced the discovery of the closest known black hole to Earth, located in the HR 6819 system in the Telescopium constellation.  Wikinews interviewed researcher Thomas Rivinius, who detailed the system's observation history, the black hole's properties (estimated mass at least 4.2 solar masses), and its visibility to the naked eye.

**2020 US Presidential Election: A Series of Interviews:** Wikinews published a six-part series on the 2020 US presidential election, featuring interviews with numerous vice presidential candidates from various parties (Constitution, Libertarian, Green, Prohibition, Alliance, Reform, Life and Liberty, Solidarity, Bread and Roses, and Unity).  These interviews explored the candidates' backgrounds, campaign strategies, policy positions, and perspectives on the COVID-19 pandemic.  The series also included analysis of key events, such as a bat attack on Jo Jorgensen (Libertarian), controversies surrounding Rocky De La Fuente's nominations, and questions about Kamala Harris's citizenship.  Further articles profiled presidential candidates Don Blankenship (Constitution), Jo Jorgensen (Libertarian), Brian Carroll (Solidarity), and Bill Hammons (Unity), delving into their backgrounds, campaign experiences, and policy proposals.


**A Water Main Break in White Plains:**  Wikinews reported on a major water main break in White Plains, New York, causing significant flooding and disruption before repairs were completed.

**Sunshine Coast Rugby Union:**  Wikinews covered several Sunshine Coast Rugby Union matches, including Caloundra's victory over Wynnum and University's win against Maroochydore, featuring post-match interviews with players and coaches.

**Melbourne Mayoral Election:**  Wikinews interviewed Wayne Tseng, a candidate in the 2020 Melbourne mayoral election, discussing his campaign platform, which focused on economic recovery post-COVID-19, inclusive governance, and celebrating Melbourne's multiculturalism.

**GitHub Blocks youtube-dl:** Following a DMCA takedown notice from the RIAA, GitHub blocked public access to the youtube-dl software.  Wikinews interviewed a former project maintainer, who highlighted the software's legitimate uses, and reported on the subsequent Streisand effect as users shared the source code via alternative means. The Electronic Frontier Foundation also commented on the incident.

**2020 US Presidential Election: Ballot Access and Policy Positions:** Wikinews reported on the Libertarian Party achieving ballot access in all 50 states, Bill Hammons' proposal to prevent Supreme Court packing, and various candidates' stances on the escalating Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict.


**CentOS's End and Rocky Linux's Rise:**  Following Red Hat's decision to shift its investment from CentOS to CentOS Stream, Wikinews spoke with members of the CentOS community about the fallout.  The article also covered the launch of Rocky Linux, a community-driven project aimed at filling the void left by CentOS.

**Extremophiles and Exoplanet Habitability:** A study showed that certain organisms could survive in atmospheres composed entirely of hydrogen or helium.  Wikinews interviewed a researcher who discussed the implications for the search for extraterrestrial life.


This overview highlights just a fraction of Wikinews' original reporting in 2020.  The diverse range of topics underscores the platform's commitment to covering a wide spectrum of news and events worldwide.

content:

Deputy Mayor Mark Reeves supported the motion, emphasizing the council's moral standing and its responsibility to represent community views. Councillor Trevor Stowe dismissed the motion as “feel-good” and unproductive.

The vote ended in a 4-4 tie, with Councillors Crook, Greacen, Reeves, and Mayor Mendy Urie voting in favor, and Councillors John White, Kirsten Van Diggele, Arthur Allan, and Stowe voting against. Councillor Sonia Buckley abstained. Mayor Urie cast the deciding vote in favor of the motion.

title: Uruguayan Language Academy rejects FA sanction against Edinson Cavani as 'poverty of cultural and linguistic knowledge'
content:

However, the Uruguayan Language Academy countered that terms like "negro" (black) and its diminutive "negrito," similar to terms like "gordo" (fatso) and "gordito," are often used affectionately in Uruguay.  The Academy's statement, signed by its president and [Minister's Title], concluded that the FA's decision stemmed from a "lack of cultural and linguistic understanding."  This sentiment was echoed by the Argentinian Language Academy, which, on December 22nd, also urged the FA to overturn Cavani's suspension.  Both academies represent the Rioplatense Spanish spoken in Uruguay and Argentina.

In a show of support, the hashtag #graciasnegrito (#thankyoulittleblackone) trended on Twitter in Argentina and Uruguay on Friday.

title: International Criminal Court rules its jurisdiction includes Palestine
content:
The International Criminal Court (ICC) ruled on Friday that its jurisdiction extends to Palestinian territories, prompting strong objections from Israel and the United States.  The 2-1 decision, detailed in a 60-page legal brief, hinges on Palestine's adherence to the Rome Statute, the ICC's founding treaty.  The court emphasized that the ruling does not address Palestinian statehood or its borders.  The judges determined that the ICC's jurisdiction extends to territories occupied by Israel since 1967, namely the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and Gaza.

Chief Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda welcomed the ruling's "judicial clarity," stating her office would analyze the decision before determining its next steps.  In 2019, Bensouda asserted that war crimes had been or were being committed in these territories, implicating both the Israeli Defence Forces and Hamas.

Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh hailed the ruling as a "victory for justice and humanity," a sentiment echoed by Hamas, the Palestinian Foreign Ministry, and Human Rights Watch.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denounced the decision as "pure hypocrisy," vowing to fight it "with all our might."  He accused the ICC of investigating Israel for "fake war crimes" and claimed the court was improperly intervening in political matters, asserting that the borders in question remain unresolved in ongoing peace talks. Israel maintains its own internal systems to prevent military misconduct, though these have faced criticism for inadequacy.

The United States, despite President Biden's stated aim to improve relations with Palestine, also rejected the ruling.  State Department spokesperson Ned Price reiterated the U.S. position that Palestine does not qualify as a sovereign state and therefore lacks the standing to join the Rome Statute or participate in international bodies like the ICC.  Price argued that the court's jurisdiction should be limited to states that consent or are referred by the UN Security Council.

Neither Israel nor the United States has ratified the Rome Statute, and both reject the court's jurisdiction.  However, Israel's construction of settlements in disputed territories, home to some 700,000 people, has drawn widespread international condemnation.

What was the basis for the International Criminal Court's ruling that its territorial jurisdiction extends into areas of Palestine?  

A) A resolution from the United Nations Security Council  
B) Palestine's membership in the Rome Statute  
C) A formal recognition of statehood by the United States  
D) An agreement between Israel and Palestine

title: New Zealand announces new Matariki public holiday
content:
New Zealand will have a new public holiday, Matariki, beginning in 2022.  The announcement was made Thursday by the government.  Matariki marks the Māori New Year and coincides with the rising of the Pleiades star cluster, known as Matariki in Māori.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern stated, "This will be a day to acknowledge our nation's unique, shared identity, and the importance of Māori culture. It's going to be something very special, and something uniquely New Zealand."  The new holiday will also address the long gap between public holidays in June and October.

The date of Matariki will vary annually, following the Māori lunar calendar (Maramataka), but will likely fall on a Monday or Friday. A Matariki advisory group, including Māori Crown Relations—Te Arawhiti—Minister [Minister's name needed here], will advise on future dates, celebrations, and public education resources. The first Matariki public holiday will be Friday, June 24, 2022.

Ardern's Labour Party made Matariki a public holiday an election promise and won last year's general election with a majority—the best result for any party since New Zealand adopted MMP (Mixed-Member Proportional representation) in 1996.

This isn't the first attempt to establish Matariki as a public holiday.  In 2009, [MP's name needed here], a Member of Parliament, introduced similar legislation.  While supported by the then-opposition Labour Party, the National Party government rejected it, resulting in a 59-63 vote defeat.

title: Arkansas becomes first US state to criminalise treatment for transgender minority
content:
Arkansas has become the first US state to enact a ban on gender-affirming care for transgender minors, defying a gubernatorial veto.  The "Save Adolescents From Experimentation Act," effective July 30th, prohibits healthcare providers from offering puberty blockers, hormone therapy, or surgery to transgender youth under 18, regardless of parental consent.  Existing patients will also be affected.  Violation results in the loss of medical license.

Governor Asa Hutchinson vetoed the bill, calling it a "product of the cultural war in America" and urging other states to resist similar legislation.  However, the Republican-controlled legislature overrode his veto with votes of 25-8 in the Senate and 72-25 in the House.

Representative [Name of Representative, District 87] defended the ban, stating that transgender youth "need to get to be 18 before they make those decisions."  Conservative groups like The Family Council praised the law.

Conversely, the American Academy of Pediatrics, representing 67,000 pediatricians, condemned the ban, citing a "general consensus among professionals" supporting gender-affirming care.  Dr. Madeline Deutsch (Medical Director, [Hospital Name, San Francisco]) and Dr. Robert Garofalo (Division Head, Adolescent and Young Adult Medicine, [Children's Hospital, Chicago]) both criticized the law as harmful to transgender youth.

Holly Dickson, Executive Director of the Arkansas ACLU, denounced the legislature's action as discriminatory and illegal, announcing plans to file a lawsuit.  The ACLU's LGBTQ & HIV project pledged its support.  This latest ban follows other anti-transgender legislation in Arkansas, including a March 25th ban on transgender girls participating in school sports, also criticized by Dickson as "discriminatory and shameful."

The Human Rights Campaign (HRC) reports over 100 anti-transgender bills have been filed nationwide, with similar proposals in at least 20 states.

[Name of outgoing MP] won the seat in the [Year of previous election] general election with 45.1% of the vote, a 13.1% margin over second-place finisher Helen McFarlane of the Scottish Labour Party (32.0%).

Wikinews interviewed Stanley on key national and local issues.  His answers to the first two questions included links to opinion pieces he authored and press releases from the Bow Group, a think tank where he serves as Senior Researcher (see External Links).

Stanley's first opinion piece advocates for housing reforms, including restricting home purchases to UK residents of ten years or more, a 20% tax on homes sold to foreigners, and the abolition of tax relief on "buy-to-let" mortgages.  His second piece criticizes a recent Scottish Parliament law, arguing it threatens freedoms and family privacy.

The Bow Group press releases focused on the COVID-19 pandemic. Wikinews interviewed Manson about key issues facing Airdrie and Shotts:

**Wikinews:** Why did you decide to run in this by-election?

**Manson:** The SDP is experiencing a resurgence across the UK, driven by growing disillusionment with mainstream politics.  People are seeking an alternative offering honest policies focused on families and communities. This is particularly true in Scotland. As Scottish Regional Chairman and a local resident for over 20 years, having raised my family in Airdrie, I’m a strong advocate for the SDP.

**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on the Westminster government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic?

**Manson:** Leading the country through the pandemic was undoubtedly challenging, and both Westminster and Holyrood made mistakes. However, excessive criticism isn't helpful. While the SDP supported initial lockdown measures, we've been critical of the subsequent stop-start approach.  This failed to suppress the virus, undermined civil liberties, and risked prolonged economic depression and societal harm.

**Wikinews:** What needs to be done to improve transport services in Airdrie and Shotts?

**Manson:** Our key transport policy is nationalizing the rail system and gaining greater control over bus services, particularly increasing funding for regional and rural routes.

**Wikinews:** Do you support Scottish independence?

**Wikinews:** What does the SDP stand for?

**Manson:** The SDP seeks the common good. We represent neither capital nor labor, but the welfare of the British people. We advocate for a social market economy where pro-public sector and pro-market policies coexist in a balanced program.

**Wikinews:** What local issue isn't being addressed adequately?

**Manson:** I'm concerned about the long-term future of sports and leisure facilities due to Scottish Government cuts to council budgets. Access to these facilities is crucial for physical and mental health, especially post-Covid.

**Wikinews:** If elected, what law would you change?

**Manson:** I'd support repealing the SNP's Hate Crime and Public Order Act. The 47 pro-democracy activists remain in detention following an alleged "primary" election, which prosecutors claim aimed to "overthrow" the government.  This follows Monday's protest outside a Hong Kong court, where approximately one thousand demonstrators demanded the release of those they consider "political prisoners."  On Sunday, 32 of the 47 were denied bail, partly due to the restrictive bail provisions within the national security laws; 15 were granted bail despite prosecutorial opposition.  The changes effectively place Hong Kong's electoral system under the direct control of the National People's Congress of China.

content:
NASA's Ingenuity helicopter survived its first Martian night alone, marking a significant milestone in the Perseverance rover mission.  The announcement, made Sunday on Twitter, confirmed the helicopter's ability to withstand frigid Martian temperatures as low as -90°C (-130°F) using its solar array to power an internal heater.  Prior to this, Ingenuity had been housed within the Perseverance rover, which provided power and warmth.  The rover deployed Ingenuity on Sunday, then repositioned itself to allow the helicopter's solar panels optimal sun exposure.

The Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) stated this successful overnight survival demonstrated the effectiveness of Ingenuity's insulation, heaters, and battery capacity.  This achievement is crucial because Mars' atmosphere is only about 1% as dense as Earth's, requiring Ingenuity's rotors to spin approximately three times faster for flight.  Its lightweight design (approximately 1.8 kilograms) aids in takeoff, while its processor boasts a power level 100 times greater than that of the Perseverance rover, according to NASA's Tim Canham.

A blade movement test was scheduled for Monday, followed by a potential first flight attempt by Sunday. This flight would be history's first powered, controlled flight on another planet.  Five flights are planned within the next 31 days, after which Ingenuity will begin collecting rock samples and photographic data. Throughout its mission, Ingenuity will also monitor its temperature and battery performance.

The Perseverance rover, which traveled 471 million kilometers to reach the Martian crater, will relay images from Ingenuity to Earth within hours of capture.  The primary mission of Perseverance focuses on searching for signs of ancient microbial life, with Ingenuity serving as a supporting element in exploration and sample collection.

title: Wikinews interviews Adrian Mizher, independent candidate for Texas' 6th congressional district special election
content:
## Wikinews Interviews Adrian Mizher, Independent Candidate for Texas' 6th Congressional District Special Election

Wikinews emailed invitations on March 23 to multiple candidates in the May 1 special election for Texas' 6th Congressional District, held to fill the vacancy left by the death of Republican Congressman Ron Wright. Adrian Mizher agreed to a phone interview on March 30 to discuss his campaign and policy positions.  The following is that interview.

Mizher, whose LinkedIn profile identifies him as a senior loan closer at [Company Name], a [City, State]-based subsidiary of [Parent Company Name], has lived in [City, Texas] for five years and in Texas for 16 of the last 24 years. A 2001 accounting graduate of [University Name] in [City, State], he grew up in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and lived for eight years in Albuquerque, New Mexico. He aims to champion "a never-ending fight for fidelity to the Constitution and promotion of our Conservative values."  The interview covered topics ranging from the economy to immigration.

An Inside Elections poll published March 18 showed Republican candidate Susan Wright (Ron Wright's widow) leading by 21%, followed by Democrat [Candidate Name] at 17%, and Republican [Candidate Name] at 8%, with 4.6% undecided among 450 likely voters. Inside Elections considers the district "lean Republican," noting it voted 51% for Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election (down from 54% in 2016).


**Wikinews:** Could you please introduce yourself, your history, and your background in politics and otherwise?

**Mizher:** My name is Adrian Mizher. I don't have much formal political experience—this is my first run for office—but I've closely followed politics my whole life. I consider myself well-informed on current issues and political history. I graduated college in 2001 with a bachelor's degree in accounting from [University Name] in [City, State]. I'm married with three children. After college, I taught history and math for five years before entering banking, where I've worked for the past 16 years. That's my résumé!


**Wikinews:** What are, in your opinion, the powers and duties of a U.S. Representative?

**Mizher:** As outlined in Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution, Congress's duties include enacting laws and upholding the Constitution against all enemies, foreign and domestic.  A representative's primary role is controlling the power of the purse and ensuring the federal budget adheres to Constitutional limitations—something clearly not happening for quite some time.


**Wikinews:** You're running as an independent in a House district controlled by Republicans since 1983, currently contested by both major parties and the Libertarian Party. Why do you think Texas will elect an independent this time?

**Mizher:** I believe voters, upon learning my views, will see they are grounded in the Constitution and Founding Principles, and are inherently conservative—principles the Republican Party should, but often doesn't, embody. Many Republicans elected to Congress deviate from their platform once in office.  Due to the unique circumstances of this special election, I initially sought to run under the Constitution Party banner. However, the [Secretary of State's] office informed me that, despite being a political party, they weren't officially registered, preventing my name from appearing under that label. My only option was to run as an independent, providing a clearer message than simply identifying as a Republican, which would have been politically suicidal in a normal election, and less likely to splinter the Republican vote in this already crowded field.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on the late Ron Wright's governance, given that his death necessitated this election?

**Mizher:** His passing was tragic. I considered Ron an excellent Congressman. We met several times, held private conversations, and I can attest he consistently followed through on his campaign promises and personal commitments to me. He voted responsibly and worked diligently.  I have only positive things to say about Congressman Wright—he served our district well.


**Wikinews:** What are some of the most pressing issues you'll raise in Congress if elected?

**Mizher:** My top priority is shrinking the federal government and budget. It's far too large, intrusive, and exceeds its Constitutional limits. We need to reverse this trend, restoring the balance of power towards state and local governments.

Election integrity is another critical issue, especially after the 2020 election. Whether or not the election was "stolen," as some claim, is debatable.  The lack of conclusive evidence on either side is problematic because the widespread belief that it was stolen erodes public trust.  We must restore confidence in our elections to prevent further unrest.

Immigration is also crucial.  The current system is flawed. We should simplify, streamline, and reduce the cost of legal immigration, welcoming those who wish to immigrate legally.  The best way to curb illegal immigration is to improve the legal process.

**Wikinews:** Your website states both "we must remain a sovereign nation in control of our borders" and "our immigration process should be simple enough that a child can follow it."  Could you elaborate?

**Mizher:**  My website also states our belief in the Biblical principle of welcoming the world's downtrodden and those seeking opportunity. We should embrace immigrants who contribute positively to our society, as past waves of immigrants have done.  Simplifying the process involves basic requirements:  no communicable diseases, no criminal history, willingness to learn English and American history, and eventual swearing allegiance to our flag and values.  Those who meet these simple requirements and pose no threat should be allowed temporary entry to pursue their goals, gradually working towards citizenship.  The current lengthy processes are unnecessary.  We need a reasonable annual cap but should prioritize those genuinely wanting to become Americans.


**Wikinews:** Your website mentions appealing to "the Supreme Judge for our guidance" and regaining "firm reliance on the protection of Divine Providence."  Could you elaborate?

**Mizher:** America's founding is inextricably linked to faith and belief in a higher power, even if not explicitly stated in all founding documents.  The founders' personal writings reveal a belief in the divine.  America has increasingly strayed from those foundational beliefs over the past half-century. Godly values, particularly Christian ones, are frequently mocked in popular culture, corroding society and contributing to various social ills. A belief in something greater than oneself provides a moral compass. Without it, individual morality prevails, leading to conflict.  I believe restoring our nation's faith in a higher power is crucial.


**Wikinews:** How would you handle the COVID-19 vaccine rollout if elected?

**Mizher:** I'm unsure if vaccine rollout is a federal responsibility. I believe we should expedite vaccine distribution and allow state and local governments to determine the best approach for their populations.


**Wikinews:** How would you help the economically disadvantaged?

**Mizher:**  The most effective assistance is delivered locally—through families, communities, charities, and state/local governments.  Federal interventions often create more problems than they solve.  Americans are compassionate and will help those in need. Currently, many avoid helping because they believe the federal government's handling of it fulfills their civic duty.  I want to shift that responsibility back to communities, fostering personal responsibility. Local assistance is more effective and allows for personalized support, working towards self-sufficiency.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on President Biden?

**Mizher:** [Laughs]  I think his agenda is too far left and unconstitutional. Like many politicians, he prioritizes satisfying his base to maintain power, sometimes advocating policies he doesn't truly believe in.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on former President Trump?

**Mizher:** President Trump achieved many great things, particularly in the Middle East peace process and Supreme Court appointments. I support his Jerusalem embassy move.  His deregulation efforts boosted the economy. However, his abrasive style hindered his ability to win over more supporters.  I appreciate his willingness to fight the left, but his methods were often overly harsh and made it difficult to defend his actions. His biggest failing was his failure to shrink the federal government; he increased spending rather than cutting it.


**Wikinews:** Do you have any thoughts on the ongoing border crisis?

**Mizher:** Both parties use the border crisis for political gain.  The situation isn't inherently different under Biden than it was under Trump, despite the rhetoric.  The solution is simple: stronger border security, increased personnel, and a streamlined legal immigration process.


**Wikinews:** Your website advocates for a "more balanced approach" to the economy, stating our societal framework is "far outside of the needed balance."  Elaborate.

**Mizher:**  I prefer free enterprise over pure capitalism, which is under attack.  Capitalism rewards greed and disproportionately favors the wealthy. Government shouldn't favor either the wealthy or the poor.  I oppose the excessive influence of large corporations that crowd out small businesses. A more balanced approach would level the playing field, promoting small and medium-sized businesses and job growth.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on the size of the U.S. military?

**Mizher:** It's too large.  The Pentagon needs to justify its massive budget.  We need to reduce spending unless compelling reasons exist for maintaining such a large military.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on the criminal justice system?

**Mizher:** The system suffers from classism, not simply racism. While racism exists and must be eradicated, the focus on racism overshadows the inequities faced by the less fortunate.  The system favors those who can afford better legal representation.  Decentralizing the system, returning power to local communities, could improve justice by fostering personal accountability and tailoring solutions to individual circumstances.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on Medicare?

**Mizher:** I believe it's unconstitutional and should eventually be dismantled. Providing healthcare is not the federal government's responsibility. State or even local governments could handle healthcare for the needy more effectively.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on the rise in anti-Asian sentiment?

**Mizher:** I'm not convinced there's a significant rise in anti-Asian sentiment.  The Atlanta shootings, for example, didn't appear racially motivated.  Any racist acts must be condemned and eradicated.


**Wikinews:** What are your thoughts on President Biden's recent talks with China?

**Mizher:** I lack sufficient information to form a solid opinion. I'm concerned Biden won't adequately challenge China's growing influence.

title: Wikinews interviews candidate for Minneapolis mayor Philip Sturm
content:
## Wikinews Interviews Minneapolis Mayoral Candidate Philip Sturm

Wikinews interviewed Philip Sturm, a candidate in the Minneapolis mayoral election scheduled for November 2, 2024.  Sturm discussed his campaign and policy positions.

Sturm is a military veteran, serving from 1999 to 2003 in the U.S. Marine Corps.  His service included a tour in Okinawa, Japan, followed by deployments to Afghanistan and Iraq during the U.S. invasions.  His civilian career is in the chemical manufacturing and operations sector.  His resume includes roles as co-chair of the DFL (Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party) District 62 in 2005, a member of Veterans for Kerry, and volunteer positions including a special deputy in Hennepin County, participation in the Minneapolis Police Department (MPD) 911 emergency helpline workgroup, and involvement with the 9/11 and GWOT Remembrance Task Force and a racial equity fund.  He resigned from the Remembrance Task Force to avoid the appearance of using it for political gain.

**Wikinews:** Please introduce yourself.

**Sturm:** I'm Phil Sturm, 40, married, and a lifelong Minnesotan.  I moved to Minneapolis in 2003 after an honorable discharge from the Marine Corps. I graduated from [High School Name Redacted] in 1998 and attended [College Name Redacted] for two years before returning to work. My current work is in the chemical manufacturing sector. I served as a Hennepin County Special Deputy (2018-2019), gaining experience in public safety and emergency management. I also participated in the MPD/911 workgroup that explored alternative emergency response models.


**Wikinews:** What motivated your mayoral candidacy?

**Sturm:** The 2020 unrest highlighted a leadership gap.  The lack of effective governance and public safety during that time convinced me that Minneapolis needs new leadership. I believe the city is plagued by incompetent, yet highly credentialed officials who consistently fail upward.


**Wikinews:** Can you elaborate on your military service?

**Sturm:** I joined the Marines in 1999, completing basic training in San Diego.  I was a combat engineer, serving initially in Okinawa, then with a Marine Expeditionary Unit based in North Carolina. I was on leave when 9/11 occurred.  My unit participated in the capture of Kandahar in December 2001, followed by patrol and humanitarian operations.  In January 2003, I deployed to Iraq. I was attached to [Unit Name Redacted] under Colonel Dowdy, responsible for managing engineering assets and neutralizing explosive devices. I returned home shortly after the initial phase of the Iraq War.


**Wikinews:** Why should Minneapolitans vote for you?

**Sturm:** I offer a different approach.  I'm an empirically-minded person with a background demanding tangible results, unlike the carousel of lawyers and professionals who consistently underperform. My leadership experience in the military and my understanding of results-oriented work make me uniquely qualified to tackle the city's challenges.


**Wikinews:** Your website states that the Minneapolis Police Department does not view itself as part of the community.  Explain.

**Sturm:** Years of “reform talks” with police chiefs and unions have been nothing but stalling tactics. They have no genuine interest in community-led reform. The MPD's culture, practices, and ideology indicate an insular and autonomous force operating outside community oversight. My campaign aims to confront this reality directly.


**Wikinews:** You also advocate for dismantling militarism within the police.  Elaborate.

**Sturm:**  My military experience led me to research the societal impact of militarism. Studies show that military occupations often exacerbate racism and xenophobia at home.  Militarizing the police mirrors this:  ostensible efforts to "help" communities often lead to increased racism within the force and its supporting structures.


**Wikinews:** Your website mentions shifting tax burdens to address economic disparities.  Explain.

**Sturm:** Targeted sales tax relief and other forms of tax relief for disadvantaged neighborhoods would effectively shift the tax burden to wealthier areas.


**Wikinews:** You support rent stabilization. Elaborate.

**Sturm:** I support an annual rent increase based on inflation plus a reasonable percentage (around 5%).  Pandemic-related measures should assist both tenants and landlords using federal relief programs.


**Wikinews:** What would distinguish your mayoral tenure?

**Sturm:** I offer a more pragmatic, data-driven approach to governance.  I will challenge the existing self-serving professional community that lacks self-awareness.


**Wikinews:** Who did you support in the [Previous Elections Redacted]?

**Sturm:** [Answers redacted to avoid endorsing specific candidates.]


**Wikinews:** How would you address educational disparities?

**Sturm:** Stable housing and food security are crucial.  We can collaborate with the school board to build on existing initiatives that link housing policies with educational outcomes.


**Wikinews:** How would you address income inequality?

**Sturm:** We must continue to support living wage policies, paid sick leave, and stable housing options.  We should foster collaborations with businesses to expand vocational and technical training in our manufacturing sectors.


**Wikinews:** [Questions regarding COVID-19 and distinguishing Sturm from other candidates received no answer.]

**Wikinews:** If you couldn't vote for yourself, who would you support?

**Sturm:**  I'm undecided, but generally support AJ Awed.

**Wikinews:** Why might people not vote for you?

**Sturm:**  Lack of executive experience and the fact that I'm another white male candidate are potential reasons.

**Wikinews:**  Which historical figure do you most admire?

**Sturm:**  [Response redacted for brevity] I admire Ulysses S. Grant for his calm and effective leadership style.  I also admire Theodore Roosevelt's positive energy.

[Concluding remarks were not provided.]


**Note:**  Bracketed information indicates redactions made for clarity, brevity, or to avoid endorsing specific candidates or institutions.  Specific names of high school, college and military units have also been redacted to protect personal information.

title: Magnitude 7.3 earthquake off Fukushima, Japan causes about 50 injuries
content:
A powerful magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck off the eastern coast of Japan at 11:08 PM local time (14:08 GMT) yesterday.  Initial reports from the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) gave a magnitude of 7.1, later revised to 7.3.  The quake's hypocenter was at a depth of approximately 55-60 kilometers.  As of late yesterday, the BBC reported around 50 injuries.  Nearly a million homes were left without power, and the shaking was strongly felt in Tokyo.

At least fourteen aftershocks have been reported by the JMA.  A JMA spokesperson warned of a heightened risk of structural collapse and landslides in areas experiencing the strongest tremors.  Prime Minister Suga Yoshihide urged residents to remain indoors and be prepared for further aftershocks.

While no tsunami warning was issued, some coastal residents evacuated to higher ground out of precaution.  One evacuee, speaking to the BBC, cited the 2011 earthquake and tsunami as the reason for their decision, stating, "Even if people say we don't need to worry about a tsunami, I won't buy it... I learned from my bitter experience 10 years ago, and that's why I evacuated."

The JMA suggested the earthquake may be an aftershock of the devastating 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami, the tenth anniversary of which is approaching.  That event claimed over 18,000 lives and triggered a nuclear accident at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant.  Prime Minister Suga confirmed that no abnormalities have been reported at any nuclear facilities following this latest quake.

title: Greek lawmakers approve contentious campus police legislation
content:
The Greek parliament passed a contentious law on Thursday establishing a campus police force and disciplinary council at universities, aiming to curb long-standing violence.  The 166-132 vote (in a 300-seat parliament) was met with opposition from students and professors who fear it will suppress freedom of speech.  The new measures include a dedicated campus police division, restricted campus access, and a disciplinary council with powers to suspend or expel students.

A government spokesperson described university campus violence as "timeless," arguing that police will remove extremist political groups, protect university infrastructure, and create a safer environment.  Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, whose center-right New Democracy party initiated the legislation, highlighted incidents of vandalism at historical university buildings as justification.

Greek universities have a history of unrest, including the deadly 1973 student revolt against the 1967-1974 military junta (resulting in at least 26 deaths), and a 1990-91 protest against high school reforms (during which a teacher died)  pushed by Mitsotakis' father.  More recently, incidents such as a rector being held hostage by masked individuals in October further fueled the government's action.  In 2019, the government lifted a 1982 ban on police entering university grounds.

Opponents argue the new police presence will stifle freedom of expression – a claim the government dismissed as "ridiculous." Recent protests have featured chants of "Bread, education, and freedom," echoing the 1973 anti-junta movement.  In January, police used tear gas to disperse a protest that violated lockdown restrictions.

Professor Dimitris Kaltsonis, Professor of State Theory and Law at [University Name], stated that  "[there is] no need for special police to control the campuses."  The University and College Union (UCU) at Oxford University expressed solidarity with Greek colleagues opposing the new force, calling the proposal "alarming and not in line with best practice."  Demonstrators have also chanted slogans like "More doctors, fewer police," highlighting concerns over Greece's high police-to-population ratio (second highest in the EU, according to 2016-2018 Eurostat data, though the government disputes the accuracy of these figures).  While the government claims it is investing in education quality, it insists the campus police are "not a choice, but a necessary move."

A recent €23 million budget allocation for law enforcement is intended to address "contemporary challenges, such as COVID-19 and external threats." The left-wing opposition party [Party Name] criticized the legislation as an attempt to create "sterile and unfree" universities.

Dávid Pethő, another nautical expert, highlighted the challenging navigational conditions of this particular section of the Danube, noting that the maneuvering required for crossing the bridge begins three kilometers upstream, leaving little margin for error. title: India records 14 millionth case of COVID-19 amid new surge in infections
content:
India's COVID-19 cases surged past 14 million on Thursday, with over 200,000 new infections—double the previous peak in September—overwhelming hospitals already operating at full capacity.  This dramatic increase, attributed to factors including election rallies, religious gatherings, and complacency, prompted the government to cite a "wilful disregard" for safety measures.  A police officer noted a significant increase in unmasked individuals in recent weeks, highlighting the ongoing challenge of compliance.

The surge propelled India past Brazil to become the second-most infected country globally on April 12th (after the United States).  Hospitals are resorting to extreme measures, including multiple patients sharing beds and converting hotels and banquet halls into treatment centers.  Several states, including Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, and Gujarat, are facing severe oxygen shortages.  The Ahmedabad Medical Association warned of rising death tolls and potential hospital closures due to oxygen depletion, urging the Gujarat chief minister for immediate intervention.

While the government insists there's no national oxygen shortage, it has shifted its vaccine focus from exports to domestic production, administering over 114 million doses—the third-highest globally after the US and China—including three million on Wednesday following the emergency approval of Sputnik V.  The government attributes inoculation distribution issues to over-planning, not supply constraints.

In response to the crisis, New Delhi imposed a stay-at-home order, closing restaurants, malls, gyms, and spas (with limited exceptions for movie theaters).  Mumbai implemented stricter measures, shutting down most industries and public places and restricting movement.  Numerous cities and towns, including the epicenter in Maharashtra, imposed curfews, limiting activity to essential services between 8 pm and 7 am.  CBSE Class 10 exams were cancelled, and Class 12 exams postponed.

The 1,038 new deaths reported Thursday—adding to a total exceeding 173,000—strained cremation and burial facilities.  India remains fourth globally in COVID-19 deaths, after the US, Brazil, and Mexico.

title: US, UK, NATO to withdraw troops from Afghanistan
content:
President Biden announced a complete withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan by September 11, 2021, ending the nation's longest war.  This decision, coinciding with the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, follows similar announcements from the United Kingdom and NATO allies, all beginning troop withdrawals on May 1st.  While former President Trump had set a May 1st deadline, Biden opted for a later date, citing the need for a responsible and safe withdrawal.

Speaking from the same room where President George W. Bush announced the initial airstrikes on Al-Qaeda, Biden emphasized that the original justification for the war no longer applies.  He stated,  "We went to Afghanistan because of a horrific attack that happened 20 years ago. That cannot explain why we should remain there in 2021. We cannot continue the cycle of extending or expanding our military presence…hoping for a different result."  He also stressed that he would not pass the responsibility of a continued US troop presence in Afghanistan onto a fifth president.

Acknowledging a likely Taliban resurgence, as indicated in a worldwide threat assessment, Biden argued against using American troops as bargaining chips in an ongoing conflict. He insisted that the withdrawal would be conducted "responsibly, deliberately, and safely."  Afghan President Ashraf Ghani tweeted his commitment to a smooth transition with US partners.

Currently, approximately 2,500 US troops are stationed in Afghanistan, part of a roughly 9,600-strong NATO mission, with an estimated additional 1,000 US special operations forces.  Combat operations for both the US and UK ended in October 2014.  While the US will cease military operations, it will continue diplomatic and humanitarian efforts in the country, according to the BBC.

NATO echoed the sentiment that a military solution is not viable and that their goal of preventing Afghanistan from serving as a terrorist safe haven has been achieved.  A joint statement declared, "Our troops went into Afghanistan together, we have adjusted together, and now we are leaving together."  Similar sentiments were expressed by Germany's Defence Minister.  US Secretary of State Antony Blinken reaffirmed the allied commitment to a coordinated withdrawal.

The UK's Defence Secretary, while expressing hope for a peaceful future for Afghanistan, prioritized the safe return of British troops.  He also acknowledged the sacrifices made by fallen soldiers.  Following a phone call with President Bush, Biden expressed shared respect and support for the US Armed Forces.

The withdrawal has drawn mixed reactions in the US.  Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell called it a "grave mistake," predicting increased terrorist threats.  Other Republicans echoed this concern, while some Democrats expressed reservations about the arbitrary deadline.  However, Senator Elizabeth Warren praised Biden's recognition that continued US presence did not enhance global security, and former President Obama voiced his support for the decision.  The CIA Director acknowledged the "significant risk" posed by Al-Qaeda and ISIS in Afghanistan, warning of potential threats to US interests.
question:
What date did President Joe Biden announce as the target for the withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan?  

A) May 1  
B) September 11  
C) October 14  
D) August 31

title: Kim Yo Jong criticizes US-South Korean military drills
content:

She further warned the U.S., saying, "If it wants to sleep in peace for the coming four years, it had better refrain from causing a stink at its first step."

Analysts offered differing interpretations.  Yang Moo-Jin, vice president for public affairs at the University of North Korean Studies, told Arirang News the message suggests a willingness to negotiate "as long as the South shows some sincerity by not raising tensions through the joint drills."  However, Lim Eul-chul, a professor of North Korean studies at Kyungnam University, believed the statement reaffirmed North Korea's longstanding demand for sanctions relief as a precondition for talks.  Finally, [Name of Director], director of the Korea Risk Group, downplayed the statement's significance, calling it "business as usual" and "pretty tame by North Korean standards," noting the recurrence of such pronouncements each spring.

At 60, he has an impressive record of service. He's a highly decorated veteran—his uniform has no room for more medals!  He lives in Midlothian, Texas, with family ties extending back six generations. He graduated from high school in California and immediately joined the military.  Later, becoming a single father, he returned to California to be closer to his children, joining the California National Guard while working in federal service.  As a non-commissioned officer and operations officer in a federal aviation unit, he supervised personnel from three different agencies.

His career encompassed diverse roles: drug interdiction in Panama and along the US-Mexico border, emergency management for the state of California, and providing security for the governor and mayor during the O.J. Simpson and Rodney King riots.  In his overseas deployments, he served in Iraq, commanding a tactical team responsible for locating high-ranking officials of the Revolutionary Guard. He also served as a provost marshal, effectively acting as police chief for a 75-mile radius.  He consistently took on leadership roles requiring problem-solving and resourcefulness.


**Wikinews:** What does he consider the primary responsibility of a US Representative?

**Chatham:** Mr. Eddings believes a US Representative's power lies in effectively serving their constituents' needs. He is concerned that many representatives prioritize narrow interests instead of the majority.  He decided to run after observing what he feels is a disregard for the oath of office among some members of Congress, believing their loyalty should be to the Constitution, not to individuals or a party. He strongly condemns the January 6th attack on the Capitol, viewing it as an attempt to undermine the democratic process, and believes the right to vote must be fiercely protected.


**Wikinews:** He's running as a Democrat in a district controlled by Republicans since 1983. Why do you think Texans might choose a Democrat this time?

**Chatham:** The district has been shifting. Tarrant County, the largest part of the district, is now considered a swing district ("purple").  In recent elections, Democrats would have won if not for Republican support in rural Navarro and Ellis counties.  However, parts of Ellis County are becoming more Democratic ("blue"), and Eddings has strong support there.  The Democratic candidates are campaigning collaboratively, rather than against each other.  Years of building political infrastructure are paying off, creating a real opportunity for change.

The district's history includes Phil Gramm, a Republican who initially lost a congressional race, then won as a Democrat, before switching back to the Republican Party after disagreements with his party. The district's economic stagnation since the adoption of trickle-down economics, coupled with job losses and increased housing and healthcare costs, has created dissatisfaction among voters. The recent Texas power outages and the perceived failures of energy company regulation have further exacerbated these issues.  There's a growing divide between Trump supporters and those who oppose his policies, and this election could be significantly impacted by that division.


**Wikinews:** Regarding the reason for this special election, the death of Ron Wright, what is Mr. Eddings' view of his governance?

**Chatham:** Ron Wright, formerly Tarrant County tax assessor-collector, closely followed the policies of Joe Barton, his former boss.  Mr. Eddings notes Wright's overtly religious displays on tax notices and government vehicles, which Eddings, while a devout Christian, finds inappropriate.  As mayor pro tem of Arlington, Wright helped facilitate the proliferation of gas wells, leading to a significant decline in air quality and damaging the city's zoning.  Wright also voted against healthcare expansion despite the district's high maternal mortality rate. He focused on protecting energy companies, even at the cost of public safety and economic opportunity.


**Wikinews:** What are the most pressing issues Mr. Eddings would address in Congress?

**Chatham:** Healthcare, affordable housing, and education are top priorities. The rising costs of these necessities far outpace income growth.  Addressing the national debt through job creation and workforce development is also key.  This includes raising wages, providing access to education and training, and creating career ladders.  He advocates for investing in American workers and technology, revising the tax code to incentivize domestic investment and research and development, and restoring the middle class.


**Wikinews:** Your website mentions the failures of "Tea Party Republicans" and "trickle-down economics." Could you elaborate?

**Chatham:** Trickle-down economics, as implemented by Reagan and Gramm, failed to deliver on its promises.  Tax cuts for businesses did not lead to increased wages or job creation. Instead, companies often banked profits or invested overseas, resulting in job losses.  This resulted in a loss of good union jobs with benefits and job security, particularly in Ellis and Navarro Counties. Eddings understands the need to support businesses, but emphasizes the importance of investing in the American workforce and offering protections for workers. The lack of such investment has left the country ill-prepared for crises, like the COVID-19 pandemic, and created numerous economic and social inequalities.


**Wikinews:** Your website states, "I served within the chain of command under the commander-in-chief, but I did not swear an oath to any one man or political party."  Please explain.

**Chatham:** Mr. Eddings believes the January 6th insurrection highlighted the danger of blind loyalty to a single individual over the Constitution.  He served under several commanders-in-chief, but his oath was always to the Constitution.  He criticizes those who excused or downplayed the insurrection and those who spread misinformation about the election. He feels strongly that a peaceful transfer of power is a cornerstone of American democracy.  His personal experiences—including returning from Iraq in a coma and undergoing extensive rehabilitation—fuel his commitment to defending the Constitution and democratic principles.


**Wikinews:** How would Mr. Eddings approach vaccine rollout?

**Chatham:** He's pleased with President Biden's approach, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive plan for distribution, including collaboration with scientists, the supply chain, the military, and healthcare professionals.  His background in emergency management gives him the necessary experience to efficiently manage such a large-scale operation.


**Wikinews:** How would he help the economically disadvantaged?

**Chatham:** Through job creation, access to education, and expansion of healthcare.  He advocates for Medicaid expansion in Texas, aiming to improve access to healthcare and lower costs for all. He also highlights the need for affordable housing initiatives and support for veterans facing housing insecurity and mental health challenges.  He would work to strengthen retirement security and prevent corporations from shirking their responsibilities to retirees.


**Wikinews:** What are his opinions on President Biden?

**Chatham:** Eddings approves of Biden's reversal of Trump's executive orders, his focus on appointing qualified officials to government positions, and his commitment to evidence-based policy-making. He supports "good government," not dismantling crucial government services.


**Wikinews:** What are his thoughts on former President Trump?

**Chatham:** Eddings doesn't hold Trump in high regard, viewing his actions as dangerous and detrimental to the nation and its allies.  He is particularly critical of Trump's disregard for intelligence briefings, his risky foreign policy decisions, and the damage inflicted on America's relationships with its allies.


**Wikinews:** What are his views on the border crisis?

**Chatham:**  Eddings acknowledges the humanitarian crisis while also understanding the need for border security. He believes a multifaceted approach is necessary, including addressing the root causes of migration in Central America, improving processing of asylum claims, and ensuring humane treatment of migrants.  He opposes building a wall, seeing it as impractical and ineffective.


**Wikinews:** What are his views on the size of the American military?

**Chatham:**  She was unable to provide a definitive answer on this topic, stating it hadn't been specifically discussed.  She did say he supports the military and recognizes its role in providing opportunities for individuals, but believes it should not be used arbitrarily.


**Wikinews:** His thoughts on the criminal justice system?

**Chatham:** Eddings supports law enforcement while acknowledging the existence of systemic racism and biases within the system. He advocates for increased transparency and accountability, citing the importance of the Sandra Bland Act and the need for similar reforms at the national level.  He supports background checks and restrictions on certain weapons while also recognizing the rights of gun owners.  He emphasizes the need to address mental health and addiction issues, utilizing trained professionals rather than relying solely on law enforcement.


**Wikinews:** What is his stance on Medicare?

**Chatham:**  He considers Medicare a highly efficient system but is open to exploring options like expanding access to younger populations or improving the Affordable Care Act to address its shortcomings.  He also advocates for expanding dental and mental health coverage.


**Wikinews:**  His thoughts on President Biden's recent talks with China?

**Chatham:**  This topic had not been discussed, so she couldn't provide an answer.


**Wikinews:** His views on the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes?

**Chatham:**  He strongly condemns all forms of hate and discrimination. He considers it an abomination.


**Wikinews:** How would he prevent the February power outages?

**Chatham:**  He advocates for federal regulations requiring winterization of energy facilities, preventing profiteering schemes, and burying pipelines at sufficient depths to prevent freezing.


**Wikinews:** What sets him apart from other candidates?

**Chatham:**  His extensive experience in emergency management, his commitment to community safety, and his dedication to finding solutions rather than seeking personal glory distinguish him. His honesty and integrity are also highlighted.


**Wikinews:** How has COVID-19 impacted the campaign?

**Chatham:**  The pandemic has drastically altered campaigning, requiring reliance on virtual communication and making traditional outreach more difficult. It also impacted the accelerated timeline of this special election, making everything more challenging.


**Wikinews:** If he isn't elected this time, what are his future plans?

**Chatham:**  He plans to run again in 2022.


**Wikinews:** Which historical figures does he most admire?

**Chatham:**  John Lewis and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, for their perseverance in the face of discrimination and their work to expand opportunities for marginalized groups.


**Wikinews:** Any final comments?

**Chatham:** [Laughs] I think I’ve said quite enough!

title: European Medicines Agency calls AstraZeneca vaccine "safe and effective"
content:
The European Medicines Agency (EMA) declared on Thursday that the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine is "safe and effective," concluding a review prompted by the suspension of its rollout in 13 EU nations.  The EMA found "no indication" of a link between the vaccine and blood clots, a concern that triggered the temporary halts.

The review analyzed safety data from over 17 million people vaccinated in the EU and UK, focusing on rare blood clotting disorders.  The EMA's Pharmacovigilance Risk Assessment Committee stated that the vaccine's benefits in combating COVID-19 (which itself can cause clotting problems) outweigh the risk of side effects.  They found no increased risk associated with the vaccine itself, specific batches, or particular manufacturing sites.  While acknowledging a possible link between very rare cases of blood clots and the vaccine,  the EMA determined that the overall number of reported blood clots following vaccination was lower than expected in the general population.  This assessment was based on over 469 reports, including 191 from the UK.  AstraZeneca also reported only 37 cases of blood clots among 17 million doses administered in the EU and UK—far fewer than would be expected naturally and comparable to other COVID-19 vaccines.

The WHO echoed the EMA's conclusion at a press briefing, urging countries to continue using the AstraZeneca vaccine.  WHO Regional Director for Europe emphasized that while the causal link between the reported cases and the vaccine remained undetermined, the benefits significantly outweigh the risks.

Many European countries, and others globally, had temporarily suspended AstraZeneca vaccinations following reports of blood clots and deaths in recipients, with some pausing specific batches.  However, numerous countries had indicated they would resume inoculations pending the EMA's assessment. France and Italy, for example, pledged to promptly restart their campaigns upon receiving positive results from the EMA review.

The suspensions have further complicated the EU's already strained vaccine rollout, hampered by supply shortages.  While French officials defended their temporary halt as justified by unusual cases,  University of Birmingham drug safety researcher Dr. Anthony Cox criticized the widespread suspensions as a "cascade of bad decision-making."
